name: Snakebird
description: Do you like puzzles, fruit and the notion of crossing a snake with a bird for no good reason? If the answer to at least one of those questions is yes, then Snakebird might be the game for you. Solve your way through this headscratcher of a puzzle game and help the snakebirds sate their hunger.

reviews.review_text: This is a *seriously* awesome puzzle game.  DO NOT let the cutesy look fool you, some of the puzzle are incredibly devious. It makes masterful use of the mechanics, in ways that will have you thinking some of the levels are impossible ... but they're not.  Definitely worth the asking price.
More clever than it looks. Reminiscent of Jelly no Puzzle.

This is a fantastic logic puzzle game. The rules are deterministic and no information is hidden - there are no 'twitch' challenges. It almost could have been made as a mechanical puzzle, like Rush Hour.
A wonderfully cute puzzle game that takes no prisoners and doesn't hesitate to throw you into a nest of snakebirds.

SHORT REVIEW INCOMING: A fun simple puzzle game that impresses with tons of charm and character. SNAKEBIRD features dozens of great designed levels which keep you interested for long amount time. But be warned: This game is not easy! It tests your puzzle solving skills better than any IQ test. An amazing puzzle game!

This game reminds me classic puzzle games: Hard and inability to pass puzzle is player's fault. If that's not your cup of tea, gtfo. Personally, I almost never play more than 20 minutes at the time. I think this is an excellent game.  Pros: Reminiscent of classical puzzle games. Clever mechanics. Good mitigation of frustration (getting stuck) for a puzzle game: 2D map for level selection and undo in map. Cutesy graphics.  Cons: No tutorials for new mechanics (or any warning): 2D map allows to play game in wildly 'wrong' order (not playing easier puzzles first that have the easier mechanics.) I guess it's experimentation aspect for the game - I didn't find it fun or interesting.  Meh: Music and sounds. Both are cute, I guess. Both started to get on my nerves after a while. Full price.  Value on sale: Great. Value at full price: OK. Value for non-puzzlers: You will lose hair.

This game is fantastic. It's simple, challenging and charming. At times it can be frustrating, but it's very much worth it and the satisfaction I felt in completing it is more than I've felt in any other game for a while now.
Confounding..

I'm not finished yet, but what a great game! The puzzles get really hard quickly but feel amazing when you solve one. Like any good puzzle game, levels often feel completely impossible until you finally 'get it'. To enjoy the game though, you have to approach it with the attitude that every level has to be earned. There are no fillers, no easy victories. this game doesn't waste your time.
It's probably the cutest thing ever to present such a huge challenge. I was expected this to be a cute little puzzle game I'd blow through then forget, but I can't beat level 3.
It's so cute it hurts, it is also secretly the devil pretending to be cute snake birds.
Oh my God, this game is way way harder than it looks. One hell of a brain-flexer.
Game of the Year.
My 4 year old daughter's new favorite game!
Is both snake AND bird? Don't be ridiculous.

Have you ever played a puzzle game?  Did you like it?  No, you didn't, because you'll like this one so much that you'll hate it, yourself, and everything else.  Please make more.  (Also, why am I so stupid, 7 stages complete and I don't know how to progress)

It is like the Devil himself designed a cutesy fun puzzlegame. Beneath the sugary surface lies an abomination, ready to strike at your brainflesh, to torture you with it's misshapen claws made of simple little problems.  Simply put, it is wonderful.
It's a bird! It's a snake! It's a brutal yet charming puzzle game!
You want a game that melts your brain while having a incredibly cute aesthetic? This game is for you.
Very challenging and satisfying puzzles
This game is insane, please play it!
The concept for this puzzle game is fantastic, but prepare to spend quite some time thinking through some tough levels.

Adorable, cartoony, and fiendishly difficult. These puzzles are so hard, so unless you're especially gifted at solving them then you'll probably end up frustrated like me. It's hard enough to have a sliding tile puzzle in which you need to map out a string moves in order to reach a goal, but most sliding tile puzzles work on a tabletop, free of external influences. Snakebird adds to the sliding tile puzzle by adding the effect of gravity. So now, the complications have doubled. You have to plan for how the Snakebird can fall. I fear that this is too tough for me.

One of the best puzzle games I've played in a long time!  I wasn't sure I was ever gonna solve most puzzles at first, some of them were just absurd looking! Some of them almost appeared to be impossible (especially the rainbow ones!).  The core mechanic is really simple, but every time you think you know how it works and what can be done with it, there's more 'impossible' puzzles thrown at you that you now how to make 'possible'.  There were really no nonsense levels (like tedious ones that are just there to pad out the game). Each puzzle do something different from the other ones and have their own solution.  I got that 'switch' in your head flipped a whole lot from when you didn't know how to solve the puzle to then understanding what the solution is(or one of them?).  If you like puzzle games Snakebird is definitly worth your time, it has pure and well designed puzzles!     The only problems I had were minor and had mostly to do with the controls.  The feedback on wich snake I just took control over wasn't very clear. I often moved the wrong snakebird (and if they fell off screen or into spikes it could get annoying sometimes because there's a little delay and the focus could switch to another snakebird).  The undo was also a bit confusing, it sometimes switches focus to the previous snakebird when you undo instead of just undoing the move you made. An example: -- There is a green and a blue snakebird. The focus is on blue. >Switch focus to green >Move >Undo It undid the move and also switched the focus to blue. --  Progress on a puzzle did not save when I exited to the map then returned to it.(it whould have been nice to have).
Brilliant game. I'm infuriated by my own stupidity already.
Puzzles are crazy hard, but solvable. Each level has different “twist”. Cannot remember any other puzzle game that good.
A very cute and hideously tricky puzzle game.

This game's puzzle mechanic is revamps the old Snake mechanic yet still manages to be unique. The puzzles are very hard, yet I still haven't given up. The puzzles tend to seem to have solutions where you can figure out fairly easily what exactly it is you need to do, but still make it hard to figure out how to do it. This makes it both frustrating and not frustrating, because at least I don't feel totally clueless most of the time.
Nice easygoing puzzle game
Got it from humble bundle. Great graphics and noises but there is no learning curve what so ever. Quite hard because of this. I guess I would recommend it but be prepared to get frustrated.
An amazing puzzle game. It uses simple mechanics to create incredibly difficult and interesting puzzles. The music is also very serene and relaxing. All in all, it's great.
This game is too damn difficult. And I am too damn bad at it. gg
Nice easygoing puzzle game

Well, see what comes out of fervently wishing for something. I've loved the indie puzzle revolution of recent years, I only wished for more difficult, more challenging puzzles, because it was really celebration time if a game produced at least a few levels that made your neurons sweat a little. And now enter Snakebird, a cute, nice-looking little game, which is really a ruthless killer of a puzzle game in candy-flavoured disguise. Snakebird wants you to collect all the fruits on a level and proceding to the exit with every one of your characters. Eating a fruit grows your snakebird with one unit, gravity works in the game, some levels provide you with simple items to help your progress, while the environment sometimes wants to kill you. There. That's it, really - and a collection of really, really tough levels, which manage to be hard without being unfair.  Snakebird is easily the best (non-construction) puzzle game I've played in a long while - I bow before the greatness of the people who designed its levels. For those who are looking for a serious brainy challenge - highly recommended.

Puzzle game with simple mechanics but very high difficulty. Simple artstyle and a nice but not outstanding soundtrack make it feel like a harder version of Hook. With the low price point a good game for inbetween, e.g. travel or similar.   Recommended if you like: High challenge puzzles, Hook Not recommended if you don't like: Puzzles (duh) Playtime: ~2-3h*, replay value probably depends on your memory   *depending on how fast you're able to solve the puzzles ofc.
Another positive review on the pile. This is not the crappy iOS game you might identify it as at first glance. Hard, clever, fun.

I'm genuinely impressed by this little puzzle game. The design of each level is incredibly clever, calculated in detail, which forces you to imagine possible paths. On top of challenging difficulty level, Snakebird offers pleasant and dynamic casual gameplay suitable for everyone.
These puzzles are made by a genius. After completing a puzzle, I'm not sure which to feel the most: good about myself, or impressed by the developer.
You're a snake now, you're a bird now. You're a snake, you're a bird, you're a snake, you're a bird. You're a snake now, you're a bird now... 10/10 Would Snakebird again.
If you like hard puzzle games which are also nice to look at and cute, get this. It's hard from the second level on O.o

Snakebird will lure you in with its comforting atmosphere and cute aesthetic. It will lull you into a false sense of security, making you think you're safe in its warm embrace. Do not let it fool you. Snakebird does not care about you. Snakebird will devour you whole the second you turn your back. Snakebird is an unrelenting, unforgiving monster constantly on the prowl for fresh blood.  The only way to escape is to beat it.

Game of the year for 2015 (for me, anyways).  Ranks up there with English Country Tune. Many puzzles simply look impossible upon initial assessment. The mechanics of the game may initially feel counterintuitive   (eg. snakebirds can stand on fruit floating in mid-air)  , but are consistent and fair. You start to develop the snakebird wiggling skills and techniques that give you an extra block or two you need, learn the proper positioning of snakebirds, and formulate the conditions required to achieve your goal. The puzzles are elegant, tight, and reduced to the essence of the concept they intend to teach you. Hypothesizing, testing, discovering, removing a patch of your own hair, and finally solving impossible-looking problems is so gratifying. As with the best puzzles you sometimes feel like you have discovered a loophole in the fabric of existence.  Graphical style and music also very appealing. A very polished work of genius.
The most difficult puzzle game I have ever played.

An incredibly tough tile-based puzzle game.  The art style & theme are things you'd see on a mobile game not at all giving the impression that the game won't be at all difficult but as the Steam store page says it's deceptively challenging.  There are a total of 53 stages, including the tutorial & extra stages, and more unlock as you keep completing stages. There's no particular order you have to do them in as the available stages are shown to you on a world map so you can basically go to another puzzle even if you've already started one. Stages don't necessarily get harder as you progress either so if say you've been stuck on one puzzle for a while you can hold that off for the time being and move on to another.  The gist of the gameplay is that you solve puzzles using a Snakebird thing with movements like in that old game, Snake. The tutorial stage will teach you how to play the game and the first few numbered stages after will basically teach you how the physics of the game work through your own experience. After all that the game will start to become noticeably difficult as the rest of the game expects you to basically be an expert in the mechanics and then some as the stages are designed to have you needing to do a a lot of figurative zigs and zags with the solutions to the puzzles. It can get incredibly frustrating with that case possibly encouraging more trial & error scenarios than thought-out ones. There's even an 'Undo' option that lets you constantly undo the last move you just did all the way from when the puzzle started in case you made a mistake. Later stages will introduce a few new mechanics you'll have to work with.  It ain't bad for something with graphics that look like they're better off in the mobile market.

It's a neat concept, however it's ruined by the frustration of trying to find the one specific solution that will beat each level. The difficulty ramps up immediately, forcing you to sit through hours of trial and error, or to seek out guides. Received from a humble bundle, otherwise would not have purchased.
Can't play. Crashed 4 times in 6 minutes.
